This Market Compass covers the Security Operations Center-as-a-Service (SOCaaS) market that continues to develop in response to demand for security monitoring, analysis, detection, response, and improvement recommendations, either instead of, or as a supplement to permanent on-premises SOCs.
15:45 • 10 days ago

KILT

Moving Through the Metaverse: The Path of Decentralization

By Ingo Rübe, founder of KILT Protocol and CEO of BOTLabs GmbH, the initial developer of KILT. The internet is evolving as rapidly as technology develops, leading to a lot of talk lately about Web3 and the Metaverse. These developments are not just about a better quality of immersive gaming, they also point to a bigger shift in the way we all live and do business. While it may take years for

By Ingo Rübe, founder of KILT Protocol and CEO of BOTLabs GmbH, the initial developer of KILT.

The internet is evolving as rapidly as technology develops, leading to a lot of talk lately about Web3 and the Metaverse. These developments are not just about a better quality of immersive gaming, they also point to a bigger shift in the way we all live and do business. While it may take years for this new era to reach maturity, now is the time to consider how it is developing and what kind of a future we want to be part of creating.

Web3

Web3 has been described as the next generation of the internet — a fairer, decentralized version where big corporations lose their monopolies and their hold on our data. Blockchain technology is a major contribution to this development, due to its ability to facilitate decentralization and enable the transfer of both data and tokens (cryptocurrencies) safely without having to trust in an individual or centralized organization.

While Web3 has been criticized in some quarters as a shift away from the free internet, it could rather be seen as a shift away from our current internet model where users are the product, with their data used and monetized by service providers.

The Metaverse

The Metaverse has many definitions. In its simplest form a Metaverse can be understood as a digital universe running alongside our physical universe. Although often associated with gaming and 3D technologies like virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR), a Metaverse can also be in 2D, like our internet or platforms that offer a way to create a second life in a digital world. These Metaverses have many of the features of our physical world. We can exist, we can interact and communicate with others, we can create objects of value, and we can own and trade things there. Therefore, these digital worlds can become a kind of reality.

Making the Connection

But as the number of Metaverses grow, so do the challenges. How do you connect your individual identity, your “me”, in the physical universe with your identity in the Metaverse? How can you move and take things with you from one Metaverse – platform, game, or service — to another? When a user connects their real-life personality and bank account to their avatar, participates in a game, and buys or wins land or accessories, how do they manage their ownership of these goods? How can digital identity and continuation of ownership extend across Metaverses?

Identity in the Metaverse

Solutions to these challenges can be found using blockchain technology. Identity in the metaverse needs to be linked to the real-life person using it. A game in the Metaverse is more than a game. It also involves in-game purchases, so as a user, you need money, and you need to store your purchases somewhere. As a player you can build a reputation and want to bring that reputation with you to other games and platforms. You may not need to know your opponent’s real name or address, but you do need to be able to identify and trust who you’re talking to, playing against, or paying for a service.

Practically, there’s also a need to provide a way for the people who build the software to earn money. And virtual things in the virtual world connect to the real world. Already, the technology exists for brands in the real world to advertise in the metaverse. Virtual billboards are owned by real people who have part-ownership of this virtual billboard, can vote on what brands get to advertise, and can receive part of the profits from this advertising. This level of complexity requires new solutions.

Blockchain Solutions

This is the point we are at now, with Web3 infrastructure that makes this possible safely. While the current version of the internet runs on advertising, in the Metaverse, work and time are valued. The principles and structures of the real world apply: If I can create something that someone wants to own, I can create a business. Anyone can start producing digital goods and data, and getting paid for it. Work, even on a small scale, is valued and rewarded.

On a larger scale, blockchain technology also provides the ability to create Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs), online organizations or companies in a virtual world that can connect to the real world. In a DAO, no one person takes responsibility or ownership, but there are rules that need to be followed. Although early DAOs failed with very public consequences — the most famous example lost the equivalent of around US$50 million worth of funding in a hack — with subsequent improvements in the technology, DAOs of the future can be created to be truly decentralized and safe, creating a whole new way of working. Anyone can work anywhere, and be paid in digital tokens that can be easily converted into the local currency.

But how do we avoid the mistakes made in Web2, where a few big corporations often have the monopoly on business and hold the data of many? Although blockchain has the potential for decentralization, it does not inherently give a guarantee of decentralization, as it can also be used to create private systems.

All technology is as good or bad as its users. Although it has often been criticized by mainstream sources as something that is used by criminals to hide their ill-gotten gains, the reality is that changes to a blockchain are generally very transparent, leaving a trail that is easy to follow once the initial address is known.

Equally, while data recorded on the blockchain can be changed, the fact that a change was made is evident. Data can be stored privately or publicly on the blockchain. Data can be distributed and stored in the cloud across several locations using services such as IPFS (the Interplanetary File System) or Filecoin. Data may be simply attested on the blockchain to say it exists or belongs to the specified owner, with only a record of the data or its owner rather than the data itself being recorded. Like everything else in life, the blockchain and its services are not black and white, and the need to do your own research (DYOR) and establish the decentralization of services you use is highly recommended.

Identity in the Metaverse is too important to be left to centralized companies. That’s where protocols like KILT come in.

KILT Protocol

KILT was built to counter monopolies and their poor handling of user data, specifically addressing the issues of digital identity in Web3. Run using on-line, transparent governance by the community of token holders, it’s a decentralized network that uses blockchain.

In the real world, identity is made up of an identifier — for example, your name — that is linked to credentials, such as your passport, driving license, qualifications, skills, etc. All these things together make up who you are.

KILT replicates this in the digital world. Digital identity is built around a decentralized identifier — a unique string of numbers and letters specific to you — and any credentials you choose to add to this identity. Credentials in the physical world can be recreated in digital form and remain with you, not with an external company, until you choose to show them. Nothing is stored on the blockchain except a proof that the credentials are still valid. Using this method means that companies can, for example, do KYC (know your customer) checks without needing to store data, reducing centralized silos that are a honeypot for hackers. Your identity belongs to you, and no external service can deny you access to your credentials.

This is the kind of decentralized identity service that is essential for the Metaverse.

The Way Forward

The changes the Metaverse brings will probably have as big an impact on our lives as the development of the smartphone. While these changes can have many benefits, they also come with the risk of repeating the mistakes of the past, handing control of our data and digital freedom to large corporations. These corporations potentially end up having even more power over us than our government does. Thanks to blockchain technology, we now have the tools to avoid recreating these issues.

Decentralization is essential for the Metaverse and has the ability to return the power to us, the users of the internet. As we move into this new era, it would serve us well to make informed choices, starting now.

Moving Through the Metaverse: The Path of Decentralization was originally published in kilt-protocol on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

14:34 • 10 days ago

Monetha

Customer Retention Tool: Everything You Need to Know

A happy customer is a repeat customer. You might have heard that phrase a lot and for a good reason. An eCommerce business cannot survive without clients who are willing to pay frequently. While new customers are hard to acquire and often lead to increased marketing costs, current customers can significantly boost your sales process and optimize your marketing strategy. What is customer retention

A happy customer is a repeat customer. You might have heard that phrase a lot and for a good reason. An eCommerce business cannot survive without clients who are willing to pay frequently.

While new customers are hard to acquire and often lead to increased marketing costs, current customers can significantly boost your sales process and optimize your marketing strategy. What is customer retention and how does it affect your finances? Let’s find out.

What is Customer Retention?

Customer retention is an important part of customer relationship management, and achieving it requires more than just keeping customers happy. It is key to any business, but it can be especially important for eCommerce businesses. As customer retention goes up, so does the lifetime value of your customer — but this only happens when you have excellent customer service. So, how can you retain customers and what are the benefits of their loyalty? Let’s see.

Why is Customer Retention Important?

If you want to lay your success on customer loyalty and build a thriving brand, then it’s critical to keep your customers happy. The best way for businesses to get better results is by listening to their feedback and addressing their concerns as soon as possible. Customer retention isn’t just about retaining your customers — it’s about knowing what they want and anticipating their needs.

1. Reduced Marketing Costs

Without a doubt, keeping your existing customers will bring a lot of value to the company. Instead of spending a fortune to acquire new customers, which isn’t guaranteed, you can decrease your marketing spending and allocate finances to other departments.

Retaining your existing clients is not just about saving a critical budget. And it also contributes to a company’s growth and raises its credibility in the eyes of other consumers.

2. Word of Mouth Marketing

We’ve all heard about the most legacy way to attract more customers — by word of mouth marketing. Customers make up your best advocates or your harshest critics, and you can decide who they will be by how you treat them.

When you take care of customers, they’ll want to tell everyone about your service. If you take advantage of this power and use this capability to maintain a positive brand image, you’re set up for success.

3. Increased Revenue

You’ve heard about the Pareto principle. 80% of the revenue comes from 20% of your clients. While it’s not 100% right, it’s very close to the truth, believe me. Loyal customers tend to spend a lot more than new customers, and the customer lifetime value can reach up to tenfold the first order.

Of course, to lift your revenue, you need to have all hands on deck — from the delivery guy to the customer service team, marketing department, and everyone in the chain.

How to Choose the Best Customer Retention Tool

There are many customer retention tools on the market. But there should be a way to differentiate the best from the good ones.

Find your customers’ needs

In the early stages of your business, the one thing you need to keep working on is understanding what your customers want. I know you want to charge ahead and create new products, but unless your customers want them, they won’t sell.

Keep listening and learning from your feedback loop — aim to gather information on how your customers prefer to pay, engage with your brand, or give feedback — because this will help you provide more personalized experiences.

Look for the right solution

To grow a business, you need to keep customers loyal. Luckily for you, there’s no shortage of customer retention tools to choose from — while a few are reasonably priced and effective, others fall under the premium segment. Experiment with different features, look at your budget and choose the best option that fits your needs.

The 15 Best Customer Retention Tools on the Market

Let’s see which customer retention tools top our list today.

1. Zendesk — The King of Customer Service

Zendesk is a help desk software utilizing integrations and automation to enable customers to fix different problems — saving you time and increasing customer loyalty. Zendesk builds each of its products to solve specific pain points in customer experience.

Optimized for large organizations, it has become a widespread tool for managing customer problems and facilitating communication between businesses and customers.

Prices start at $49/month on an annual plan, but you will get a lot of features — like an industry-leading ticketing system, over 1,000 apps and integrations, a smooth user interface, and up to 500 automated answers.

2. Hubspot — The Gatling Gun of CRMs

While many tools are available to help marketers improve their outreach, Hubspot can be considered the best of its kind. And no, it’s not just hype: the software has dozens of features, including dynamic personalization, custom data analysis, customer satisfaction surveys, omnichannel automation, A/B testing, and predictive lead scoring.

Of course, that doesn’t come cheap. The starter plan costs $45/month, but it is nowhere as good as the advanced ones. Businesses with lots of customer data and contacts may pay thousands of dollars to get hold of the platform. While it’s a great customer engagement platform, it’s not a solution targeted at everyday small businesses.

3. Optimizely — test, test, test, repeat

Optimizely helps businesses transform their digital products through the power of experimentation from startups to large enterprises. By leveraging the platform’s top-notch web, mobile, and API testing solutions, businesses can easily create personalized experiences for their audience and make data-driven decisions with confidence.

Optimizely empowers marketers to generate leads, increase conversions, and boost sales through personalized marketing campaigns.

If you can afford to spend between $50,000 and $200,000 per year on software, you can gain more loyal customers, reward returning customers, and identify repeat customers and new prospects.

4. Qualaroo

Qualaroo provides a simple, straightforward way of collecting real-time feedback from your customers — whether you’re looking to improve the customer experience on your website or you want to understand what’s working and what isn’t.

Qualaroo is ideal for both. Its easy-to-use surveys and insightful data help businesses collect intelligence and make better decisions.

To be fair, this is one of the more budget solutions on the list. It starts at $80 per month, but for $160/month, you can get more than decent features — like integrations, branding, advanced targeting, and exit surveys.

5. Zoho CRM

Zoho is a business software suite that businesses can use to make their lives easier. With over 50 online apps such as Zoho Docs, Zoho Books, and Zoho Expense, it can help keep track of everything you need, from inventory and projects to employee expenses and customer orders.

Zoho provides affordable customer retention business software for SMBs to manage time, projects, and client relations without the overhead cost of dedicated enterprise solutions.

The Indian platform has a free plan for up to 3 users, but the other plans are reasonably priced. For SMBs who want to elevate their customer retention rate, a Standard plan costs $14/month, and the Professional plan costs $23/month.

But even the most premium one (the Ultimate) is not expensive — $52/month. Bear in mind these prices are at an annual rate.

6. LoyalZoo

The LoyalZoo software lets businesses of all shapes and sizes create customer loyalty programs that appeal to their customers’ unique needs. LoyalZoo is easy to set up and use to avoid having much trouble with the platform.

Businesses can then share the reward system online and on mobile with their customers — orchestrating a seamless customer experience that’s both efficient and highly rewarding.

The platform is relatively cheap, and it charges per store rather than per user, which is a massive boost. $47 is the base plan. If you want to create SMS marketing campaigns, you will have to pay $30 extra, but it is totally worth it.

7. Thanx

Thanx has taken digital and brick-and-mortar loyalty programs to the next level. Businesses can reach out to their best customers and deliver a personalized experience without the inconveniences of old-fashioned, manually updated details.

By streamlining the system and creating an algorithm that automatically rewards regular customers, Thanx helps businesses crank over the wheel of their most profitable customers.

Considering some previous options, the prices start from $99 per month, which isn’t cheap. Nonetheless, not many apps allow you to interact with guests, so the app is worth a shot. Let me try it, Thanx!

8. Yotpo

Yotpo helps businesses build relationships with current and potential customers. Their eCommerce marketing software allows users to leverage customer feedback to improve lead generation and sales. The platform features a centralized location where users can publish content, conduct polls, and collect reviews.

The system stores all the data related to the customer and their purchase history. It helps businesses grow by being sure that they are offering a satisfactory shopping experience to their customers.

Yotpo starts at $19/month (the Growth plan). However, as your needs grow, so does the pricing. The Prime plan costs $59/month, but you should have deeper pockets if you want to access AI-powered predictive segmentation and unlimited A/B testing. That’s what you pay for using a legacy name in the industry.

9. Mailchimp

Seriously, is there a chart where Mailchimp doesn’t participate? Jokes aside, Mailchimp is an all-in-one marketing tool that can help you increase your reach while reducing your costs. Its built-in eCommerce features, landing pages, and digital ads have helped a lot of businesses in their growth journey.

And due to its powerful integrations with Zapier, Slack, Canva, and WordPress, it is set up for success. So, yes, it is on our list for a reason!

The software is also very balanced in terms of pricing. It has a generous free plan, and the starting plan is only $11/month. Of course, it can reach more than $1,300 for 200k+ contact in your email list, but still — it has something for everyone.

10. Heap Analytics

Heap Analytics is so much more than a client retention tool. From understanding customer behavior to improving personalized experiences, Heap can be used to enrich your business. The best part? They’ve got an intuitive interface that even people who aren’t tech-savvy can use.

The platform is refined and very detailed. Well, you price the price for it is steep — the Growth plan starts at $3,600 per year, but it can get tenfold the amount.

11. Litmus

Using Litmus’ robust tools, you can create beautiful and effective emails that will engage your customers. With these email templates and drag-and-drop elements, and Litmus’ expertise, you can make sure most campaigns resonate with your potential and current customers.

It’s all about making your customers feel in control of their experience with your brand.

Litmus Basic starts at $79/month, but if you have a small team, you can jump to Litmus Plus — it costs $159/month, but it gives you five user seats, as well as spam testing, QA testing, code editor, and productivity integrations all at the same place.

12. Amplitude

Amplitude gives you all the tools to analyze user behavior to know what’s working and what isn’t. With features like grouping users based on their activities and recording information down to the session level, Amplitude helps your business understand which parts keep customers engaged.

It’s a leading platform, but you can’t see any pricing when you go to the website. You can find sources online that indicate you have to pay between $5,000 and $100,000 per year, so you’ll spend a lot.

13. Crazy Egg

Crazy Egg’s heatmaps allow users to see where their visitors are clicking and what webpages are, resulting in qualified leads. The tool automatically creates A/B tests for essential landing pages so that brands can increase conversion from visitors to leads, sales, and more loyal customers.

There are no free plans, but Crazy Egg doesn’t charge a fortune either. Its pricing plan starts from $24 per month up to $249 per month, and it’s worth the cost of the product. With over 300,000 users, it’s on the list of best tools to generate heat maps and simple click-tracking data.

14. Woorise

Woorise is a one-stop-shop for all of your marketing needs. This customer retention tool provides the features to create engaging contests, landing pages, and giveaways. Build your email list and drive new sales by offering a fabulous prize and incentivizing people to enter.

Make your brand fantastic! A well-designed landing page can help you raise leads, generate sales, and build your database at lightning speed.

Woorise is so well-built, but also it is very reasonably priced. There is a free plan, and the starting plan is only $23/month. The Grow plan is $39/month, and Pro starts at $79, but it won’t exceed $900 per month.

15. Monetha for Business

Monetha for business (monetha.io/business) is a part of the Monetha platform that allows shops easily create their loyalty programs, and these points can be used within the whole Monetha platform. On top of that, you get built-in customer analytics and a chance to join the network of Monetha.

It’s a very ambitious project, and it even has a cryptocurrency coin (MTH)! Monetha is arguably an up-and-coming customer retention tool with a bright future for its worth.

Originally published at https://www.monetha.io.

12:30 • 10 days ago

Dark Matter Labs

DM Note #8: On Art and Imagination Infrastructure

DM Note #8: On Art, Imagination Infrastructures, and Shared Memories of the Future This is the 8th in a series of DM notes, which share information and insights from DM Downloads — our regular internal learning sessions. The aim is to make our practice more legible, for us as well as for you. DM Note #8 is an opportunity to reflect together on the role of art: in making the future pres
DM Note #8: On Art, Imagination Infrastructures, and Shared Memories of the Future

This is the 8th in a series of DM notes, which share information and insights from DM Downloads — our regular internal learning sessions. The aim is to make our practice more legible, for us as well as for you.

DM Note #8 is an opportunity to reflect together on the role of art: in making the future present; in expressing our ideas in ways that are more tangible and visceral at early stages; in building imagination as a civic-infrastructure for tomorrow’s societies; in valourizing “softer” and often neglected ways of knowing and exploring; and a lot more.

DM might have started with a design and architecture focus, but it’s become increasingly transdisciplinary, including expertise in: financial structuring, governance innovation, international law, real estate, policy and regulatory design, and full stack development. In this DM Note, we reflect on the role that art plays (or could play) in our practice.

Our Free House initiative, whose various parts are being developed with different partners in various locations, had its first material incarnation at the Museum of the Future in Dubai recently, as a small model with augmented reality. Building Imagination Infrastructures

We work on various novel, entangled, tangible and intangible types of civic infrastructure (Trees As Infrastructure being one of the most advanced examples), and recently we have started exploring imagination infrastructure, which falls within intangible infrastructure. Here’s our current working definition for intangible infrastructuring, which Linnéa, Mihai and Anjeline have been working on within DM:

the shared recipes, relationships, and abilities that underpin society’s social, ecological, and economic systems.
It refers to the process of using and creating these to scaffold functionings and values at a societal scale.
They emerge through interactive processes between diverse actors and tangible structures in a given context, relative to each actor’s conversion factor.
Intangibles enable the reduction of fundamental uncertainty, prevention of damage, and most importantly fulfill conditions for societal thriving.

At an event in June 2021 organized by the Community Fund, Indy from Dark Matter Labs was on a panel discussing how we define infrastructure, and unpicking what it means to use the term in the context of something as intangible as imagination.

When we think of infrastructure, we might think of roads or telephone lines, durable built environments, technologies that encode relationships and political ideas, and structures that drive how we interact with each other. Infrastructures are collective and cooperative ways of supporting our individual and shared agency and our ability to live our lives according to certain values. The juxtaposition between infrastructure and imagination is useful because it reminds us that imagination doesn’t happen as stroke of genius, it requires scaffolding, especially when thinking about collective imagining.

Since the beginning of the pandemic, our challenge was somehow to collaborate globally to return to the normal we knew, while the climate breakdown requires us to collaborate at various scales around transitioning into a new normal. How can we build a deeper democracy of the imagination, so as to better be able to see and feel the kind of futures we want and need? How to do so in a way that is intrinsically motivated, and contextually enabled? How to liberate other ways of sensing and knowing that allows our minds to help each other travel to places unknown, in new expressions of our shared humanity? And how to do that in a context where uncertainty and complexity seems to be increasing?

This won’t happen all by itself; it will also require significant care and investment. It can easily be dismissed by governments and policy makers as a simple nice-to-have that can’t be a priority right now, but it is increasingly fundamental if we are to organize into bigger and bigger groups of humans and transition towards more regenerative futures that we can’t yet see or feel. Repeating facts about climate change is part of the work of changing how we understand our roles and impact in this world, but it is insufficient by itself.

Experiencing Possibilities Now: Economic Art as a Practice

From early childhood we are trained to believe that a good amount of money corresponds to a safe life, a happy life. In some senses that is true, but it has created a snowball effect where there is no clear idea on how much capital one single person actually needs to be, and feel, safe and happy.

For people and organizations attempting to thrive in this tumultuous time, fixed mindsets and stagnated approaches no longer work. To create a better future where everyone can flourish, leaders and organizations need to find brave ways to engage and encourage emotions more fully, but also truly comprehend how they connect us to the economic systems we have created.

How can we make more concrete and palpable new economic systems with experiences that guide us through deeper exploration in soft values, vulnerability, culture, dark matter, unknowns, emotions, radical innovation, gender, politics, economy, storytelling.

This is what Jenny from DM has been exploring from Sweden, in partnership with SVID. Within Economic Spaces, we have started working on public art installations and exhibitions. We share our thoughts and what has come out of learning, studying and discussing with partners, organizations and citizens with both shared and oppositional mindsets. The purpose of these installations is to create real world tangible experiences of future economic possibilities whilst prototyping the dark matter innovations necessary for this future.

Through art we can emotionally introduce ourselves to a whole new set of experiences and ideas that we may have never witnessed before. Rather than only discussing climate change, economic powers and human behaviours through distant science and hard-to-grasp technological language we can provide space to emotionally connect our experience of the world through current realities.

“Economy” encompasses more than money and finance; in the recent DM Download Jenny framed economy as the larger, more holistic space in which we interact and share, care (or not), perform acts of generosity and create mindsets for a sustainable future. In this sense, an economy can be softer, more emotional and filled with innovation. Economic Spaces is an exploration in having new dialogues about all of these types of economies. It is an invitation to be remarkably creative in finding new ways to explore an economy with a comprehensive understanding that we are free.

The Use of Participatory Futuring
to Craft Shared Memories of the Future

Hollywood blockbusters and Netflix series made countless films imagining the end of the planet as we know it, from alien invasions to fertility decline, yet none that shows a plausible end and desirable alternative to the problematic aspects of our current economic systems. Why?

Partly because we live in an age of communicative capitalism where our attention span is being fought over by multinational corporations, where short-termism is the norm across sectors, where inequalities and scarcity steals mental capacity beyond more urgent needs, and where the most visible long term visions are those of billionaire space explorers, authoritative governments and private tech companies. Furthermore, our collective imagination is constrained by inherited 19th-century world economic models that have become second nature; like water to a fish. As a consequence, our future is colonized by our past and the few, and our imagination is constrained to the point of feeling almost broken.

But it is not broken; we just need better imagination infrastructure which, unlike state-led top-down propaganda of the past world wars, will provide us with more legitimate and collectively-led narratives towards socio-ecological transition. It might be easy to dismiss powerful stories and narratives in the necessary social transformations to come, but it would be underestimating how essential it has always been in enabling large-scale numbers of humans to cooperate effectively in history. Unlike other animals that evolve only through their DNA alone, humans can bypass their genome through cultural evolution.

As Jonathan from DM in Montreal pointed out in his presentation, the army and large corporations have already been hiring science fiction writers to better anticipate and predict the future, but where are similar resources for society’s shared transitions? Humans are not as rational as the age of enlightenment might have made us believe. As we are entering the age of entanglement, we will need to not only plan for better futures but also to imagine and experience them today in a manner that is so visceral that we start building memories of these futures and start caring about the generations that will inherit them. According to neuroscience research, going through an immersive experiment of futuring activates the regions of the brain associated with memory. We are literally creating memories of the future, which can help keep ideas viscerally alive in a community passed short-term political cycles.

Call it cathedral thinking, but for our economic systems.

A preview of the workshop on the future of rights of nature — Biosphère, Montréal

In 2019 DM organized a workshop at the Biosphere in Montreal on natural ecosystems, as part of the preliminary reflection with Radicle and ExpoLive leading to the Dubai World Expo and with the McConnell Foundation. We invited various Indigenous leaders, scientists, environmental activists and legal experts to reflect on the future of rights of nature in Canada. We started with a preliminary scenario of five rivers being granted rights of nature in 2040, and the challenges and possibilities that would emerge from that. We then invited the participants to speak in the present tense about life around them in 2040. The first person to speak began: “Since I became the first Indigenous Prime Minister of Canada last year, I decided to…”. and instantly, a higher level of creativity and freedom flew through the conversation. Instead of bumping against each other’s current positions, people were weaving their imaginations together to embody the full complexity they represented into a future scenario.

Two years later, when the first river was granted rights of nature in Québec, Jonathan from DM shared that the first thought that came to mind was “Oh, I remember that”. Because it “happened” in that workshop, without any sophisticated immersive media or technology; just through the power of shared projection and imagination. What could we achieve if we brought that to a whole new collective level, using all the power of the most recent advances in media, art and technologies?

Some case studies of the role of art, culture and digital technologies, in participatory futuring (In French) From Strategic Foresight to Participatory Futuring

As the growing uncertainty of the world is recognized, methods such as predictive forecasting that pretend to predict the future have become almost antiquated, while strategic foresight has become increasingly used by various levels of government and institutions as a way not to predict the future, but to prepare strategies that are robust across a range of plausible futures.

However, as explained by Nesta in this report on participatory futures (which we inspired ourselves from for this work): rarely are the strategic foresight exercises moving beyond a few actors (small groups of academics, corporations, and government teams) or beyond certain mediums (written reports with a few diagrams). Participatory Futuring aims at creating a democratized body of collective intelligence on exploring and shaping the future using some of the most engaging, visceral, and tangible cultural, mediatic, and artistic tools out there.

Engaging groups in this process has the promise of creating better policy-making, more effective socialization of emerging technologies, and greater legitimacy for hard decisions, as well as creating the constituencies for long-term change that can survive political cycles, through the creation of shared memories of the future.

This process involves working together to:

Inspired by Nesta’s Report — Our Futures: By the people, for the people

Participatory Futures set out to bring people together to think about the future and inform collective actions in the present. The involvement of, for example, artists in the process invites people to engage in the process without defaulting to the limits of traditional problem framing, or the rational, linguistic categories that may constrain the full range of possibility and desire.

The design of a participatory futures exercise depends on the strategic impact desired, the scale of engagement, and the way the future or alternative futures are going to be used. Through many case studies we looked into, it’s increasingly clear that art and culture are crucial to cultivating long-term attitudes and behaviours. They are foundational in shaping our collective direction of travel, from the kinds of laws we make, to the technology we develop, to the way we think about our role in shaping the future.

Over the past few years, Dark Matter Labs explored this emergent practice thanks to the support of the McConnell Foundation, and worked on various exploratory pieces of research relevant to the topic, including the Futures in Longtermism series and the Future Generation Desk at the Office of Rules and Norms, initially hosted at the Art Faculty of Concordia University in Montreal. For this last one, we worked with two researchers, Joelle and Maddy, to answer the following question: How can we invite future generations in present negotiations to influence current decision-making processes? The final report explores the diverse possibilities of theatrical, interpersonal experimentations and creative bureaucratic practices for long-term decision-making. Read more about it here.

We are also looking to explore how art could be channelled into the development of Radicle Civics — looking at how art as a social practice could expand the comprehension of now and allow us to see the world differently, and shift the Overton window. Please do stay in touch here if you’re interested.

Summary Slide from Radicle Civics Art as the Next Frontier of our Transdisciplinarity:
Political Legitimacy and Movement Building

In January 2020, at the dawn of the coronavirus crisis that would soon shake global society to its core, Quebec’s TVA network began airing a series titled Épidémie (Epidemic) about the outbreak of… a coronavirus

The parallels between the fictional show and reality are astounding: the same type of virus (Coronavirus) with a similar name (Cova instead of Covid), challenges in getting people to take the virus seriously, racism linked to the origin of the outbreak (in the show, people call it the “Inuit virus”), shortages in vital supplies such as masks, etc…

How did that happen? The screenwriters based their scenario on scientific papers and predictions from health organizations, but brought it to a much wider audience than traditional reports could ever dream of.

Uncanny to say the least, this eerie parallel between fiction and reality-to-come is indicative of the ways in which creative speculations on the future can illuminate pitfalls of current ways of thinking and living and accurately depict catastrophes to come and ways to address them — the same way fire emergency and evacuation rehearsals have become mainstream in many buildings.

What if that TV show had been done years ago, not only as entertainment, but as a way to better anticipate known risks to come and better prepare for it together?

Traditional policy making as usual simply hasn’t had all the answers. Can the Arts sector — under pressure with increasing reduced or restricted funding streams and the impact of Covid-19 — be empowered and more importantly equipped with the resources to provide some new policy tools? Can the Arts sector help civil society to mobilize and find solutions and tools to address the wicked problems of our society in new ways? Zehra argued in her presentation that the civic movement to address certain wicked problems such as climate change is already there — at least in the UK, and that DML and many other organizations looking at using Art and imagination infrastructure can help provide the tools and direction for the right interventions. One example of that is our recent involvement with UNDP North Macedonia, where we did some very preliminary work on how to think of imagination Infrastructure as scaffolding for distributed collaborative capabilities at a national level.

Here’s a preliminary process that we are working on of how participatory futuring could work at a societal scale (in French)

Indeed, to mobilize systems change, the state has to enable and provide the scaffolding for distributed collaborative capabilities across society. In this age of complexity, top down government is neither sustainable given the scope and scale of interventions required, nor effective given the range of actors involved in an interconnected nation system. Moreover, the increased risks faced by the nation system need bold interventions that require building legitimacy across society for such actions.

The Overton Window is a model for understanding how ideas in society change over time and influence politics. The core concept is that politicians are limited in what policy ideas they can support — they generally only pursue policies that are widely accepted across society as legitimate policy options. This window of politically acceptable options is primarily defined not by what politicians prefer, but rather by what they believe they can support and still win re-election or secure election. However, the Overton Window can shift and expand to include different policy options when ideas change in the society that elects them.

We have to build the imagination infrastructure of society as whole because currently the limitation is not what politicians can say or do, but rather our collective sense-making as to the future — that can then become a reinforcement for political action. Without investing in societal sense-making of the future, we cannot create pathways for transition as the Overton window is currently too small to deal with the scale of the challenge presented by this age of uncertainty.

Imagination infrastructure constructs the space for the organizational transformation that Governments require to meet the challenge of transition. This learning process also allows the public to recognize that there are no linear futures. It fundamentally transforms the relationship between citizens and the state to a new societal contract. The question becomes not what can a Government do but how will it do so.

Imagination infrastructure provides a simple structure to shift the Overton window from politicians to communities. Civic duty is moved far beyond merely exercising a right to vote to becoming part of a more inclusive, deliberative democracy that can hold our interdependencies. This is about democratizing the future, enabling citizens to dream and contribute to shaping our collective futures. It builds trust and a new language of the future.

Furthermore, the reality has been that too much of Government policy has been based on the imagination of a few policy makers or legislators, and that can create blindspots. Imagination infrastructure serves to break down the silos in the machinery of the state. It democratizes the ability to create the shared worlds that further unlock hallmarks of humanity (such as creativity and care). It builds the societal capacity to deliver the NDS with a whole of society approach, and new societal sense making capabilities for the future.

Governance as system transition challenge — From our #NextGenGov (the Big Boring Bureaucratic Revolution) blog in November 2018 Strategic considerations to build political momentum around imagination infrastructures: Increasingly difficult + vital — We live in an age of disinformation, increased polarization and distractions, and difficult living conditions, yet this work has never been more important. Furthermore, given that many political and government actors are dealing with scarce resources, it might be difficult to convince public authorities that this kind of imaginative and futuristic take on governance and planning is worth spending time or money on. How to reconcile these tensions? Lack of evidence / The challenge of the first mover — Often governments won’t be able to justify investing in that kind of practices until it proves effective. Evidence based reductionist / analytical thinking is currently the dominant style, and proving that other forms of knowing could provide serious insights for decision makers might be a challenge, especially since there isn’t yet clear impact measurements for participatory futuring mechanisms, as Nesta justly points out in its report. Yet if every actor waits for that evidence, we will never move forward. Where do we even create authorizing spaces for that kind of work with governments, and who will be willing to be the first movers and investors on this? Long term and expensive — Much of this work cannot be done on a tight budget or short term, which goes against many current constraints. How do we build that in? How do we create, restructure or reorient current funding opportunities to be open to that kind of work, whether it comes from the art and media sectors, public participation offices, or others? One example is the new strategic innovation fund from the Canada Council for the Art, which we have contributed to the reflection of in the past few years. Communities of practice and impact — One pathway to success is to build a coalition of collaborators — that each have a value system that is truly open and about citizen engagement. Of course a lot of this work is very contextual, but there can still be shared resources on some levels. How do we learn across experiments in a way that informs everyone? What strategies for network development help scale ﬁndings in ways that are accessible and deployable beyond the limits of each project? Becoming legitimate / Being taken seriously — There can be a gender and race dynamic with this work. Women (and qualities that have been reduced to femininity) and ethnic minority practitioners (and their deeply culturally rooted alternative worldviews) will say this sort of work is hard enough to do, but you also struggle to be taken seriously doing “softer work” as a woman, ethnic minority person, etc. Can we build concrete utility and social legitimacy around these conceptual and practical approaches to knowledge production, for the benefit of all? Building shared language across practices — This work requires interdisciplinary working;rtists, policy and finance specialists, etc.. Language tailored to our audience matters, but many practitioners needed aren’t used to do this work either. How do we train both artists and non-artists in engaging with participatory futuring methods, for instance? How do we connect the right artists and arts practices with the right opportunity or challenge? Impact measurement / Evaluation — What methods can we use to frame explicit, anticipated goals, and take meaningful measurement of impact?
What methods of data collection and interpretation ensure results are transferable? How does measurement and evaluation feedback into framing methodology? The potential roles of art in our practice: Art for internal sense-making — How to walk the talk with how we design the organization and our initiatives? Art as a strategy for engagement — How can art help us organize communities of practice around complex topics? Art as change-making and subversive agent — How can art accelerate the materialization of our ideas by intervening in grey areas of regulation Art as pedagogy — How to make public various forces and forms of influence that are often invisible Art as decision-making — How to reorient modes of knowing and deliberating so that they take into consideration more aspects Art as shared joy — How can working and living with art make our lives more meaningful and joyful. The role of the art sector

As we wrote about with Mass Culture and David Maggs in Canada, the relationship between art and society has always been in flux, the past few years has been unprecedented thanks to four distinct disruptions: The disruption of activity, stemming from COVID-19; the disruption of society, emerging from rising social unrest; the disruption of industry, based on the digital revolution; and the disruption of world, rooted in the sustainability crisis. Here, the arts sector finds its business model on life support, its purchase on the public imagination in decline, and its relationship to social issues insufficient. As we try to reinvigorate the relationship between art and society, two linked capacities may be helpful: 1) identify an explicit grasp of its unique value proposition — what does art do better than anything else?; 2) couple that recognition with an increased capacity to understand social challenges in terms of the capacity we offer — what are the arts-shaped holes in our worlds right now?

Happily, the answer is, many. An increasing number of challenges have reached the limits of rational, analytical problem-solving and are searching for ways to transform traditional thinking, shift collective practice, and reimagine underlying assumptions. As a result, arts-shaped holes are emerging everywhere. Consider climate change. Here, the science and technology of the crisis are largely resolved. We know enough about the problem and have the solutions needed to fix it. And yet our imaginative horizons balk at a post-carbon existence. So just when many countries’ arts sector is on the ropes, the capacities of creative practices are emerging as critical to some of our most urgent needs. Here we arrive at the relationship between art and social transformation.

How do the arts contribute meaningfully to challenges in socio-ecological transformations without simply defaulting to communication exercises? How do we bring the elusive agency of the aesthetic to concrete social problems? And how do we measure the effects of having done so? The art space has the potential to expand the boundaries of the current legitimate conversation — vital to making the transition — by asking key structural questions, questions outside the current orthodoxy of thinking, acting and doing; and yet critical from our perspective.

A shift in our hearts, bodies and minds

This work might require an important shift, because we have been trained to value forms of sensing and knowledge that can be more easily demonstrable and measured in a certain way, and to repress others as invalid, illegitimate, impertinent, not very serious, or too soft. The kind of work we are discussing in this DM Note can’t be done via the analytical brain alone, and requires us to be more vulnerable, by jumping into the unknown with others, with no assurance of what exactly will come out of it, yet hoping for the needed visceral and exciting shared memories of futures we want to work towards together.

And if it’s true that experiencing effective participatory futuring exercises can create shared “memories” of the future, how can we build from what we understand about the brain and memory functions to build a more collective imagination infrastructure?

We end this DM Note with some inspiration from Pixar’s movie Inside Out. ;-)

Get in touch

If you enjoyed this 8th DM Note, you can clap the article to show appreciation, read all of our previous notes here, and follow us on Medium for more. Please feel free to reach out and share your thoughts on this as we continue to grow a community of interest/ practice/ impact around the world.

Jonathan Lapalme
jonathan@darkmatterlabs.org
Laboratoires de matière sombre — Dark Matter Labs Canada

Jenny Grettve — Economic Art
Mörk Materia Laboratoriet AB / Dark Matter Labs Sweden
jenny@darkmatterlabs.org

Zehra Zaidi — Policy
zehra@darkmatterlabs.org
Dark Matter Labs UK

DM Note #8: On Art and Imagination Infrastructure was originally published in Dark Matter Laboratories on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

12:05 • 10 days ago

Jelurida Swiss SA

Jelurida Becomes A Gold Member of Lugano’s Ticino Blockchain Technologies Association

Jelurida Becomes A Gold Member of Lugano’s Ticino Blockchain Technologies Association Tue, 2022-04-26 - 14:03 Jelurida Becomes A Gold Member of Lugano’s Ticino Blockchain Technologies Association U.Today: Jelurida is pleased to announce its partnership as Gold Member with the Ticino Blockchain Technologies Association, which combines blockchain and crypto organization
Jelurida Becomes A Gold Member of Lugano’s Ticino Blockchain Technologies Association Tue, 2022-04-26 - 14:03 Jelurida Becomes A Gold Member of Lugano’s Ticino Blockchain Technologies Association

U.Today: Jelurida is pleased to announce its partnership as Gold Member with the Ticino Blockchain Technologies Association, which combines blockchain and crypto organizations based in Lugano, Switzerland, and connects them to universities and research centres for private and public projects. Jelurida’s developments and expertise will be used by a new audience of future builders, innovators, and individuals pursuing industry careers. Jelurida’s core technology and products, Ardor, Ignis and Nxt blockchains, are designed to fuel ongoing blockchain industry growth and help establish new use cases, cooperation, and research, thus expanding the Swiss education system as a whole. Since Lugano is quickly turning into a hub for blockchain and crypto, Jelurida is happy to join the TBTA and contribute to the success of Lugano Plan B.

April 26, 2022

12:03 • 10 days ago

SWN Global

Introducing Pairwise Trust, A New Blockchain-Based Identification Solution for Web3 Infrastructures

“Pairwise Trust” now available on MetaMUI SSID In the ever-evolving digital society, one of the most important thing is to control one’s digital identity and digital property. Since the invention of the internet, it has brought great advantages for people to send, receive and exchange information, data, and even money through the web in real time. The internet has given us an exciting space an
“Pairwise Trust” now available on MetaMUI SSID

In the ever-evolving digital society, one of the most important thing is to control one’s digital identity and digital property. Since the invention of the internet, it has brought great advantages for people to send, receive and exchange information, data, and even money through the web in real time. The internet has given us an exciting space and boundless possibilities. However, at the same time, it brings great risks and responsibilities to users, although many people have not noticed it yet.

There are many risks while using the internet, and one of the critical issues for all the internet users is that the users can get damages by accessing a wrong website by putting wrong address, or entering a phishing website with exposing personal data. Some people might say that it won’t happen to them, but in reality, it actually happens and can happen to all the internet users. It causes lots of property damage, and personal information leakage.

In 2019, the FBI(Federal Bureau of Investigation) documented a record $3.5 billion in losses due to internet crimes (2019 Internet Crime Report Released) and in 2021, the losses became almost doubled($6.9 billion). (2021 Internet Crime Report)

Internet Crime Statistics for last 5 Years
(“2021 Internet Crime Report”)

As mentioned earlier, these internet crimes usually happen to the users who registered their personal information to a wrong website or provide personal data to a web service provider which sells the data to unknown third parties.

To prevent these billions of losses and crimes, and make the internet a safe and reliable place, MetaMUI team has developed an ultimate blockchain-based identification solution called “Pairwise Trust”. Pairwise Trust is a security protocol that verifies the identities of both parties in a transaction simultaneously, powered by Two-Way Cryptographic Binding.

Pairwise Trust runs on MetaMUI, the world’s first identity-based blockchain, and 4th generation blockchain which provide the Identity Blockchain. In MetaMUI, users can create their own DID by submitting their personal information(KYC) to one of the Sidechain Operators, and the operator will decide whether approving or denying the request depending on the status of the submitted data. Once the request is approved, the user’s personal data get hashed, and the hashed data is safely stored in the user’s device. In the case of Public DIDs, a KYC provider is exclusively operated by MetaMUI, so operators such as all other stores, banks, and public institutions can have their own public DIDs with the approval of MetaMUI.

Non-individual companies and institutions will be issued a Public DID rather than a Personal DID, and the issued Public DID will be disclosed as a Public DID on the MetaMUI SSID. Users can access the correct website by searching and clicking on the Public DID in the MetaMUI SSID. Furthermore, MetaMUI SSID supports an integrated DID log in solution. It enables the users to log in any websites without registering a new ID and password but only with DID. Once a user log in through MetaMUI SSID app with his/her DID and connect to online stores by searching it on the Public DID list, the user can safely buy goods, groceries and products without exposing personal data. There is no risk to enter wrong websites.

In addition, MetaMUI users can check their personal transaction records and check their balance using the Pairwise Trust after accessing MetaMUI Blockchain Explorer(https://scan.metamui.id/dashboard). While most public blockchains, including Bitcoin and Ethereum, are disclosing the user’s transaction data on its explorers, MetaMUI prevents personal information leakage and ensure safe transactions by allowing only the owners to view their transaction records.

Pairwise Trust is a strong safeguard to protect user’s personal information not to be leaked by accessing wrong websites, and users don’t need to provide personal data to use any website or app but just use their DID. Pairwise Trust is a safe bridge between the real world and the Metaverse world, and will position as one of the important roles for Web3 infrastructures.

About MetaMUI

MetaMUI is the world’s 1st Identity-based blockchain to truly enable regulated Peer_to_Peer (P2P) transactions. It can be used as the cornerstone for most financial offerings, with its high versatility and support for custom-developed use cases that enable Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDC) implementation and issuance easily on the MetaMUI CBDC platform.
MetaMUI is built around Self-Sovereign Identity (SSID) technology. By combining the SSID and blockchain token mechanism, MetaMUI was able to create a new identity-based CBDC system that can protect user’s privacy while providing an identity-based transfer system that can satisfy travel rules and other regulatory requirements such as Know your customer (KYC), Anti-money laundering (AML) and Counter Financing of Terrorism (CFT).

Website/Linkedin/Twitter/Telegram/Youtube/Medium

09:56 • 10 days ago

Cozy Cloud

Does a perfect password exist?

The perfect password doesn't exist, just like the password you wrote down on that post it that uses your mother's maiden name with your daughter's birth date. We explain why a password manager can help you. The most used passwords in France‌‌

The perfect password doesn't exist, just like the password you wrote down on that post it that uses your mother's maiden name with your daughter's birth date. We explain why a password manager can help you.

The most used passwords in France‌‌

In 2021, the most common passwords are weak. As the top 10 most used passwords in France show, all of them are decipherable in less than 1 second by malicious people. Since 2018, the number sequence 123456 remains number 1 in the ranking. In 2021, this password has been used more than 103 million times.‌‌France appears among the countries with a high risk index, with more than 406 million disclosed passwords, or 6 on average per capita, in 2021.‌‌

Here are the top 10 most used passwords in France:‌‌123456‌‌123456789‌‌azerty‌‌12345‌‌000000‌‌tiffany‌‌qwerty‌‌1234561‌‌loulou‌‌marseille‌‌

The weak link in computing is most of the time not the software but the human.‌‌

The recommendations of the ANSSI

‌‌The ANSSI (National Agency for the Security of Information Systems) has published recommendations for the creation of secure passwords. We share them with you.‌‌

Use a unique password for each service. In particular, the use of the same password for both your professional and personal email accounts should be avoided. You can use a password manager like Cozy Pass to have your passwords with you at all times without having to remember them. We had written a comparison of the different password managers available on the market. Choose a password that is not related to you (password made up of a company name, date of birth, etc.); Never ask a third party to generate a password for you; Always change default passwords as soon as possible when systems contain them; Renew your passwords with a reasonable frequency. Every 90 days is a good compromise for systems containing sensitive data; Do not store passwords in a file on a computer that is particularly exposed to risk (e.g., online on the Internet), let alone on an easily accessible paper; Do not send your own passwords to your personal email; Configure software, including your web browser, so that it does not "remember" chosen passwords.

Data theft is a reality. Forgetting passwords is a daily occurrence.

Two methods to choose your passwords:‌‌- The phonetic method: "I bought eight CDs for a hundred euros this afternoon" will become ght8CD%E7am ;‌‌- The first letters method: the quote "one yours is better than two you'll get" will yield 1yibttu'lg.

‌‌💡 You can also calculate the strength of a password with the ANSSI tool. This will allow you to know the strength of your password: Calculate the "strength" of a password

A capital letter (see +) A minimum of 8 characters One or more special characters One or more numbers Does not contain your first or last name Does not contain your date of birth Does not contain your nickname‌‌ A password manager to get rid of 123456

As far as the password is concerned, you should know that a hacker will not look for your password at random, he will look for information about you:‌‌

Your first and last name‌‌ The first names of your relatives‌‌ The name of your pet‌‌ Your habits (if you are a sportsman, there is a big chance that your password is something related to sports)‌‌ Your date of birth.

A password manager is a very simple tool that holds your passwords for you, automatically enters them as you browse the internet, and makes it easier for you to shop online.‌‌The latest barometer on digital practices and personal data control published at the end of 2019 (before the health crisis) shows a four-point increase in the use of a password manager among men and 25-34 year olds. With the health crisis, this usage must have increased further.

At the launch of Cozy Pass, some Cozy users told us that they were already using the Apple Keychain or Chrome, and that they didn't see the need for a password manager.

‌‌Many users save their passwords in Chrome or Firefox without even realizing it. When you're surfing the Web, a pop-up window appears asking you to save the password, and you click yes or no. When you come back to this page later, your password may be saved.

‌‌But you'll run into a problem when you try to log into an account from your iPhone while browsing the web with Safari. The passwords you saved on Chrome are then not available. Even worse, the passwords saved in Keychain may be different! You might even find yourself in a situation where you reset a password because you can't access a certain account, rendering the password saved in Chrome invalid.‌‌This situation can drive you crazy and is not sustainable over time.‌‌Maybe you use Chrome at home, but if your company's network only allows Internet Explorer or Firefox, your passwords stay "at home.

Cozy Pass users can easily access all of their passwords on all platforms, whether they use a PC for work, a Mac at home, an Android device or an iPhone. Cozy Pass works on all devices and all browsers even from their Cozy web interface. So your passwords follow you wherever you go. No black boxes. No duplicates. Only you have control.‌‌

The bottom line: as our personal and professional lives become increasingly digital and the vast majority of people use multiple devices in different ecosystems, an effective password management solution must work everywhere and when asked "how do I make a perfect password?", a password manager can help you get rid of post-it notes and other "password woes".‌‌

But keep in mind that the weakest link in computing is most of the time not the software but the human being.‌‌

To learn more about the Cozy personal cloud and its password manager, Cozy Pass, go to our page.‌‌

For those who want to install an extension on their favorite browser‌‌

Chrome‌‌ Firefox‌‌ Safari‌‌

For those on the go, Cozy Pass is also available on mobile

🐙 Android

🍏 iOS

Thank you for reading this article 🙌.

The Explorer Mindset with Simona Pop | Layer Zero

This episode takes place in the geographical heart of Layer Zero: the middle of DevConnect, the 2022 Amsterdam conference. With the backdrop of a lively conference center, Simona Pop explores heavy topics like the 1989 Romanian Revolution and the pitfalls of DAO governance.   When you cut off the head of top-down totalitarianism, you must replace it with something better—otherwise, anothe

This episode takes place in the geographical heart of Layer Zero: the middle of DevConnect, the 2022 Amsterdam conference. With the backdrop of a lively conference center, Simona Pop explores heavy topics like the 1989 Romanian Revolution and the pitfalls of DAO governance.

 

When you cut off the head of top-down totalitarianism, you must replace it with something better—otherwise, another hydra head will appear. Simona thrives on the cutting edge of big problems like these, working on DAO Engagement Strategy at Gitcoin, Community Strategy at Status, and founding the Bounties Network.

 

When Simona talks about crypto and the Web3 space, the epic proportions of this moment in history become clear and present.

Durante la sessione, analizzeremo con l’aiuto di Dario Grilli – Dottore Commercialista, le conseguenze del decreto legge 228/2021 sui bilanci delle società in perdita. Inoltre, grazie al

InfoCert e Verbalizza presentano il Webinar “Novità per l’approvazione del bilancio 2021 in perdita”. L’evento si terrà live il prossimo 27 aprile dalle ore 17:00 alle ore 18:00.

Durante la sessione, analizzeremo con l’aiuto di Dario Grilli – Dottore Commercialista, le conseguenze del decreto legge 228/2021 sui bilanci delle società in perdita.

Inoltre, grazie alla partecipazione degli esperti InfoCert e Verbalizza, presenteremo le ultime novità in materia di Digital Trust pensate per il mondo dei Professionisti, come Verbalizza, la prima piattaforma che consente di gestire in digitale le assemblee dei soci e le riunioni del CdA con redazione del verbale in real time.

Iscriviti ora al webinar!

Agenda:

Il Digital Trust InfoCert per i professionisti e la collaborazione con Verbalizza – Paola Di Fisco | InfoCert PMM Novità per l’approvazione del bilancio 2021 in perdita – a cura di Dario Grilli | Dottore Commercialista  Sterilizzazione delle perdite 2020 e 2021 Verifica del presupposto della continuità Aziendale Profili di responsabilità degli amministratori
